Hong Kong: A City Divided Photographs by Lam Yik Fei Nov. 23, 2019
THE PROTESTS IN HONG KONG began as a mass expression of frustration over a contentious bill. They have evolved into a violent fight over the future of this Chinese territory.

Tunnels, bridges and even the airport have been shut down. Campuses have become battlegrounds. Streets are filled with smoke and tear gas. And thousands have been arrested.

To the protesters and their advocates, it all represents a movement to protect the city’s freedoms and defend democratic ideals.

To the government, the police and their supporters, it is a threat that is damaging the economy and undermining society.

Both camps are made up of individuals. Their motivations and perspectives differ. Their means vary. But they all have the same goal: defending their city.

These are the faces of the unrest.

THE FIGHTERS
Dressed in black, they run directly into the fray, wielding umbrellas and Molotov cocktails. They clash with the police at the frontlines of the fight, facing injury, arrest and an uncertain future.

“I try my best to keep up with my studies, but the resistance comes first.”
Kenny
High School Student

“Freedom and rights can’t be asked for — you have to fight for them.”
Fat Boy
College Dropout

“I am really worried about the future. If I get arrested, can I face my family?”
Donna
University Student

“Normal people would try to avoid dangerous places. As frontliners we try to rush over there.”
Coco
University Student

“I am not a brave warrior. I am afraid of dying.”
Sing
Construction Worker

THE ACTIVISTS
In a leaderless movement, they are the closest thing to leaders, a collection of lawmakers, celebrities, activists and others trying to bring global attention to their cause. They have found inspiration in previous pro-democracy demonstrations, including the Umbrella Movement of 2014, for which some were arrested.

“If the government falls into totalitarianism and oppresses people, then we have no choice but to rebel.”
Joseph Zen
Catholic Cardinal

“Death threats are already part of my daily routine.”
Joshua Wong
Social Activist

“Our crime is to participate in protests.”
Agnes Chow
Social Activist

“I realized that I can use my voice in more ways than one.”
Denise Ho
Cantopop Singer

“After I was disqualified from running for office, I lost hope. But this city is worth it — we should not give up on politics in Hong Kong.”
Ventus Lau
March Organizer

“I am simply trying to do the work of a democratically elected lawmaker: to be a protector.”
Roy Kwong
Pro-Democracy Lawmaker

“We have so many young people — we should offer as much help as we can.”
Tanya Chan
Pro-Democracy Lawmaker

THE ADVERSARIES
Among those who oppose the protests, there are hard-liners eager for Beijing to intervene. There are moderates who want dialogue with the demonstrators. And there are the defenders of the police who want to see order restored.

“What Hong Kong people are doing now is a betrayal of the motherland.”
Lau Siu Kai
Adviser to Beijing

“Provided you don’t touch the so-called red line to suggest independence, anything is negotiable.”
Ronny Tong
Executive Council Member

“Their professions don’t mean they aren’t people. They bleed a lot, too.”
Grace Kwong
Pro-Police Rally Organizer

“If you want Hong Kong to be stable, you have to have a strong police force.”
Innes Tang
Pro-Police Rally Organizer

“Their real objective is to take over Hong Kong.”
Regina Ip
Pro-Beijing Lawmaker

THE SUPPORTERS
More than a million people took to the streets in the early days of the protests, a sea of parents, students, retirees, professionals — people rich and poor. Since the police no longer grant permission for large-scale marches, the protests don’t attract the same numbers. But public support remains strong.

“When I was detained, I would knock on the walls and try to ask who else was on the other side.”
Grace
High School Student

唉

“Visual elements in these protests trigger emotions I can’t feel. But the scenes are very much alive to me.”
Billy Wong
Visually Impaired Student

“Modern mothers will not only take care of the children — they will also wear sneakers to participate in social movements.”
Suzanne Choi
University Professor

“We can’t lose now, because the Chinese Communist Party is slowly taking away our freedoms.”
Ryan
High School Student

“Many of us swam to Hong Kong in search of freedom.”
Chan Hak Chi
Retiree

THE ALLIES
Behind the scenes, the protests are backed by a vast network of people who tend to the injured and counsel the arrested. Some have special skills, playing music in flash-mob orchestras or providing medical attention to the wounded. Others cook meals or drive carpools.

“I sing and play the violin. Other than action, it’s easiest to touch people through music.”
Kath Lit
Protest Orchestra Member

“I sometimes feel like a den mother. Once one kid gets to know you, all of their friends will call you.”
Norris Chan
Pro-Bono Lawyer

“The government ignores you and has stopped approving peaceful protests. I have nothing left to say. So in the end, I can play music in public to encourage others.”
Cy Chan
Protest Orchestra Member

“As silver-haired people, we have to do something special. We want to put ourselves between the police and the protesters, to try and protect the kids.”
KC Law
Retiree

“I have not slept at home for almost a month.”
Ryan Lee
Volunteer Medic

“We wouldn’t chant, we wouldn’t touch any weapons, we wouldn’t touch tear gas canisters. It would affect the neutral image of first-aiders.”
Tung Au Yeung
Volunteer Medic

“In protest events, we are looked upon as foreigners or tourists. We always say we are Hong Kongers, too.”
Ansah Malik
Social Worker

THE CASUALTIES
The damage is personal and professional. The economy is in recession, hurting businesses large and small. Protesters and politicians have been attacked or lost their jobs. One woman became a symbol of the protests after she was hit in the eye with a projectile.

“I admit that I feel fear after my attacks. But I wouldn’t choose to lower my head in fear.”
Jimmy Sham
March Organizer

“Only in a totalitarian, distorted society would people be forced to defend it with life and blood.”
K
Volunteer Medic Struck in the Eye

“I own seven restaurants, and in the course of five months I’ve had to close six of them. But I wouldn’t condemn the protesters — this is a social problem.”
Mog Koo
Business Owner

“Tear gas grenades seared my press vest. My thighs, waist and stomach were scorched. I didn’t stop until a few hours later when they started swelling.”
Ronson Chan
Journalist

“I lost my job. But now I can say anything I want.”
Rebecca Sy
Former Flight Attendant

Some participants have not been identified with their full names to protect their privacy.

Photo editing by David Furst and Mikko Takkunen. Design and production by Matt Ruby, Rumsey Taylor and Josh Williams. Lighting design by Ian Kirby and Stuart Hendry. Additional reporting by Ezra Cheung, Austin Ramzy and Keith Bradsher.
